samples.prompt: Post the opening paragraph to a book or story you want to write.
samples.output:
**Opening Paragraph to *The Hollow Crown***

The storm had come without warning, as storms often do in these parts. The wind howled through the skeletal branches of the blackthorn trees, their gnarled fingers clawing at the sky as if trying to escape the earth. Rain lashed the cobblestones of the village square, turning the dust to mud, and the flickering lanterns cast long, trembling shadows against the crumbling stone walls. The villagers had barricaded themselves inside their homes, whispering prayers to gods who had long since turned their backs on them. But in the heart of the storm, where the thunder roared like a beast unchained, a single figure stood motionless in the square, his cloak billowing like the wings of some great, fallen angel.

His name was Elias Veyne, and he had come for the crown.

The Hollow Crown was not a thing of gold or jewels, not a symbol of power or glory. It was a relic, a cursed thing, said to be forged from the bones of the first king who had ruled these lands. It was said that to wear it was to invite madness, to hear the whispers of the dead, to see the ghosts of those who had once worn it before. And yet, Elias had come for it. Not for glory, not for power, but because he had been promised answers.

The storm had followed him since he crossed the border into the ruined kingdom of Varethis. The villagers called it an omen, a sign that the gods themselves disapproved of his quest. But Elias knew better. The storm was not a warning—it was a herald. The Hollow Crown was calling to him.

And he would answer.

---

**The Hollow Crown** is a dark fantasy novel that follows Elias Veyne, a disgraced knight turned mercenary, as he seeks the legendary Hollow Crown—a relic said to grant its wearer the power to hear the voices of the dead. But the crown is cursed, and those who seek it often find themselves consumed by its whispers. Elias’s journey leads him through a land ravaged by war and superstition, where the line between myth and reality blurs, and where the dead do not always stay buried.

The story explores themes of guilt, redemption, and the price of power. Elias is haunted by his past—by the lives he has taken, the oaths he has broken, and the kingdom he once swore to protect. The Hollow Crown offers him a chance to right his wrongs, to hear the voices of those he has failed, but at what cost? As he delves deeper into the mystery of the crown, he uncovers a conspiracy that threatens to unravel the very fabric of the world.

The novel blends elements of political intrigue, gothic horror, and epic fantasy, with a richly detailed world where magic is rare and dangerous, and the dead walk among the living. The Hollow Crown is not just a relic—it is a key to a forgotten history, a history that could either save the world or doom it to eternal darkness.

Would you like me to expand on any particular aspect of the story, such as the worldbuilding, the characters, or the central conflict?

samples.prompt: : You are missing an eye, and hate being asked about the eyepatch. There's nothing you like less than having to explain the story of how a single acorn once saved your life.
samples.output:
**The Acorn and the Eyepatch**

I hate the eyepatch.

Not the way most people hate things—like bad weather or slow internet. I hate it with the kind of quiet, simmering resentment that comes from something you can’t escape, something that’s become a part of you whether you like it or not. The patch itself is fine, I suppose. It’s black, plain, unadorned. No skulls, no silver filigree, no dramatic flair. Just a simple piece of fabric covering the empty socket where my left eye used to be.

But people *love* to ask about it.

“What happened to your eye?”
“Did you lose it in an accident?”
“Was it a fight?”
“Did you get it shot out?”

The questions never end. And the worst part? The story behind it is so *stupid* that I’d rather not tell it at all. Because the truth is, I lost my eye to an acorn.

Yes. An acorn.

It wasn’t a dramatic battle. There was no heroic last stand, no daring escape, no grand sacrifice. Just me, an oak tree, and a single, perfectly aimed projectile of fate.

I was twelve years old, climbing trees like I always did—recklessly, without a care in the world. My friends dared me to go higher, and I, being the kind of kid who couldn’t resist a challenge, scrambled up the trunk of the oldest oak in the park, branches groaning under my weight. The higher I went, the more the wind picked up, and the more the leaves rustled above me. I didn’t think much of it. Trees were my domain. I was fearless.

Then, without warning, the wind shifted.

It was one of those sudden gusts that seem to come from nowhere, the kind that makes you stumble if you’re not braced for it. But I was already off-balance, one hand gripping a branch, the other reaching for the next. The wind hit, and the tree shuddered. A single acorn, ripe and heavy, dislodged from its perch high above.

I didn’t even see it coming.

One second, I was laughing, the next—*thunk*. The acorn struck me square in the left eye with the force of a bullet. The pain was blinding. I screamed, lost my grip, and fell.

I don’t remember the fall. I don’t remember hitting the ground. The next thing I knew, I was in the hospital, my mother crying, my father pale with shock, and a doctor explaining that my eye was beyond saving.

An acorn.

That’s the story. That’s the whole thing. No dramatic backstory, no tragic twist. Just a stupid, freak accident that left me with a patch and a lifetime of awkward explanations.

People don’t believe me when I tell them. They think I’m joking. They laugh, or they raise their eyebrows, or they say, “No, really, what *actually* happened?”

I wish I had a better story. I wish I could say it was a shrapnel wound from a war, or a duel gone wrong, or some kind of heroic sacrifice. But no. It was an acorn.

And now, every time someone asks, I have to relive that moment—the wind, the fall, the way the world went dark on one side. I have to see the pity in their eyes, or the barely suppressed amusement, or the way they glance at my patch like it’s a joke.

I hate the eyepatch.

But I hate the story even more.

samples.prompt: "Baby, did it hurt when you fell from heaven?"Her eyes swiveled to mine in panic and her eyes flashed golden briefly, and asked with a shocked and slightly apprehensive expression "How did you know about that?"
samples.output:
**Baby, Did It Hurt When You Fell from Heaven?**

The words slipped out before I could stop them, a fleeting thought given voice in a moment of vulnerability. Her eyes, wide and luminous, flicked to mine with a sharpness that betrayed her sudden unease. For a fraction of a second, they flashed gold—like sunlight striking honey—but then she blinked, and the color was gone, replaced by a guarded expression. Her voice, when it came, was quiet, laced with something between fear and accusation. *"How did you know about that?"*

The question hung in the air between us, heavy with unspoken meaning. I had no answer—at least, none that made sense. It was just a phrase, a fragment of a song, a poetic way to describe something beyond ordinary experience. But the way she reacted—it was as if I had struck a nerve, uncovered a secret she had spent a lifetime hiding.

I hesitated, searching for the right words. "It’s just something people say," I offered weakly. "A figure of speech."

Her gaze didn’t waver. "Not like that," she said, her voice barely above a whisper. "Not with *that* look in your eyes."

I frowned. "What look?"

She exhaled sharply, her fingers tightening around the edge of the table. "The way you said it… like you *knew*." There was a tremor in her words, a flicker of something raw and unguarded. "Like you’d seen it happen."

A chill ran down my spine. I hadn’t meant to imply anything—I hadn’t *known* anything. But now, looking at her, I wondered. There was a weight to her presence, something intangible yet undeniable, like she carried the memory of wings that had once been spread wide. The way she moved, the way she sometimes looked at the sky as if she recognized it—it was as if she had once belonged to something greater.

"You’re not…" I trailed off, unsure how to even phrase the thought.

She didn’t let me finish. "No," she said, but there was no conviction in it. Just exhaustion.

I leaned forward, my voice low. "Tell me."

For a long moment, she said nothing. Then, slowly, she turned her head toward the window, where the last light of dusk bled into the horizon. "It was a long time ago," she murmured. "Before I was human. Before I was *anything* like this."

I held my breath.

"Falling isn’t the right word," she continued, her voice distant, as if she were seeing it all again. "It was more like… slipping. Losing my grip on something I never fully understood." She laughed softly, bitterly. "Heaven. That’s what people call it. But it wasn’t a place. Not really. It was a state of being. A moment before the first breath, before the first thought. Before the world told you who you were supposed to be."

I swallowed hard. "And then?"

Her eyes met mine again, and this time, they were full of sorrow. "And then I opened my eyes, and I was here. Alone."

The words settled between us, heavy with implication. I wanted to ask more—to demand answers, to know how something like that was even possible—but the moment felt fragile, like a bubble that might burst with the slightest touch. Instead, I reached out, my fingertips just brushing hers.

"Does it still hurt?" I asked softly.

She looked down at our hands, and for the first time, something like peace crossed her face. "Not as much as it used to."

Silence stretched between us, but it wasn’t uncomfortable. It was the kind of quiet that comes after a revelation, when the world feels both smaller and infinitely larger all at once.

I wondered if she had ever told anyone else. If anyone had ever asked the right question at the right time, or if she had spent centuries carrying this secret alone. The thought of it broke my heart in ways I couldn’t explain.

"Will you tell me more?" I asked.

She smiled, just a little. "One day, maybe."

And for now, that was enough.

samples.prompt: Humans figured out in the future that mothernature was slowly killing the human race by evolving viruses and climate change. You are the last human to be alived.
samples.output:
**The Last Human: A World Without Us**

The air was thick with silence. No birds sang, no wind rustled through the trees—only the distant hum of a dying world. I sat on the cracked concrete of an abandoned city, my breath shallow, my body weak. The last human. The final witness to the end of our species.

It had taken centuries for us to realize the truth: Mother Nature was not our ally. She was our executioner.

### **The Awakening**

The first signs were subtle. A few decades ago, scientists noticed an alarming trend: viruses were evolving faster than ever before. What had once been a slow, predictable process of mutation now seemed almost deliberate. Deadly strains emerged with terrifying speed, bypassing vaccines before they could be developed. Pandemics became annual events, each one deadlier than the last.

At first, we blamed ourselves—pollution, deforestation, the reckless exploitation of natural resources. But then the climate models changed. The Earth was not just reacting to us; it was *adapting*. The planet had become a living, breathing entity, and it was fighting back.

### **The Great Unraveling**

The turning point came when the first "intelligent" viruses appeared. They didn’t just kill—they *learned*. They evolved to target specific immune systems, rendering vaccines useless. Governments collapsed as healthcare systems failed. The last human civilizations clung to survival, but the damage was irreversible.

Then came the climate shifts. The weather patterns that had sustained life for millennia destabilized. Droughts lasted decades. Storms grew in intensity, wiping out entire regions. The oceans turned acidic, killing off marine life. The food chain collapsed.

We tried to fight back. Geoengineering projects, massive carbon capture initiatives, even desperate attempts to terraform other planets. But it was too late. The Earth had decided we were the disease, and it was purging us.

### **The Last of Us**

I don’t know how I survived. Maybe it was luck. Maybe it was fate. But here I am, the last human alive.

The cities are ruins now, overgrown with vines and moss. The air is thick with pollen from plants that have evolved to thrive in a world without us. The animals that remain are different—smarter, more adaptable. They watch me with cautious curiosity, as if they know I am the last of a dying breed.

Sometimes, I wonder if the Earth ever truly wanted us here. Were we just an experiment? A failed species that overstayed its welcome? The planet has healed itself before—after the dinosaurs, after the great extinctions. It will do so again.

### **The Final Message**

I write this not for anyone to read. There is no one left to hear it. But perhaps, in some distant future, another species will rise, and they will find these words. Maybe they will learn from our mistakes.

Or maybe the Earth will decide they are the next threat.

I don’t know how much longer I have. My body is failing. The last of the antibiotics ran out months ago. The food is scarce, the water contaminated.

But I will keep writing. Because if there is one thing I’ve learned, it’s that the Earth does not forgive. It does not negotiate. It simply *is*.

And in the end, that was enough to wipe us out.

I am the last human. And soon, I will be gone.

Goodbye, world. You win.

samples.prompt: What started as a fun little mystery made by a group of kids to amuse their detective friend for their birthday turns into a full-fledged FBI investigation.
samples.output:
**The Birthday Prank That Turned into an FBI Investigation**

It started as an innocent prank—a harmless little mystery crafted by a group of kids to celebrate their friend’s birthday. What they didn’t realize was that their playful deception would spiral into something far more serious, drawing the attention of the FBI and turning their small town into the center of a national investigation.

### **The Setup: A Birthday Surprise**

The group of friends—Jake, Mia, Ethan, and Zoe—had always been creative, especially when it came to pranks. Their friend, Detective Sam Reynolds, had a sharp mind and a love for solving puzzles, so they decided to give him the ultimate birthday gift: a mystery to unravel.

They spent weeks planning it out. They left cryptic notes around town, staged a fake break-in at the local diner, and even planted a few "clues" that led to an abandoned warehouse on the outskirts of town. The final clue was a map pointing to a locked chest buried in the woods, which they filled with fake evidence—old newspaper clippings, a toy gun, and a note written in code.

They knew Sam would love the challenge. He was always the one who solved their riddles, and this was their way of giving him a real detective experience.

### **The Investigation Begins**

On the morning of Sam’s birthday, the friends gathered at his house, pretending to be just as confused as everyone else. "Did you hear about the break-in at the diner?" Jake asked casually. "And now there’s a map leading to some kind of treasure?"

Sam, ever the detective, was immediately intrigued. He gathered the clues, analyzed the notes, and followed the trail just as the kids had hoped. By the time he reached the warehouse, he was convinced he was onto something big.

But then, things took an unexpected turn.

### **The FBI Gets Involved**

One of the notes the kids had left—meant to be a red herring—contained a phrase that, when decoded, resembled a real criminal code from an old FBI case. The warehouse they had chosen just happened to be the same one used in a real investigation years ago.

When Sam reported his findings to the local police, they took it seriously. The FBI was alerted, and within hours, agents were swarming the town, treating the kids’ prank as a potential lead in an unsolved case.

The friends panicked. They had never intended for this to go this far. They tried to come forward, but by then, the FBI had already started digging deeper. The fake evidence they had planted was now being treated as real, and the more the agents investigated, the more they believed they were onto something.

### **The Unraveling**

The kids tried to confess, but no one believed them. The FBI agents thought they were covering up something bigger. The local news picked up the story, and soon, the entire town was buzzing with theories about a long-forgotten crime resurfacing.

Sam, realizing the truth, finally put the pieces together. He confronted his friends, and they admitted everything. But by then, the FBI had already spent weeks investigating, and they weren’t about to let a simple confession dismiss their work.

### **The Aftermath**

The FBI eventually concluded that the case was a hoax, but not before the kids faced serious consequences. They were questioned for hours, their homes were searched, and their reputations were temporarily tarnished. The town, which had once been a quiet, peaceful place, was now the subject of national headlines.

In the end, the kids learned a hard lesson about the consequences of their actions. What started as a fun birthday prank had turned into a full-blown investigation, teaching them that even the most innocent of jokes could have serious repercussions.

### **The Lesson Learned**

The experience changed the friends forever. They realized that their actions had real-world consequences, and they vowed never to take their pranks so far again. Sam, though initially frustrated, forgave them, understanding that they had never meant for things to escalate this way.

The town eventually returned to normal, but the story of the birthday prank that turned into an FBI investigation became a cautionary tale—one that reminded everyone that sometimes, even the best intentions can lead to unexpected chaos.

samples.prompt: You're writing a horror novel, and the events in the book start happening in real life.
samples.output:
**Title: The Unseen Script**

The first time it happened, I thought it was a coincidence.

I was sitting at my desk, staring at the blank screen of my laptop, fingers hovering over the keyboard. The cursor blinked mockingly, as if daring me to begin. I had been struggling with writer’s block for weeks, unable to find the right words for my horror novel. The story was supposed to be about a small town plagued by a series of inexplicable disappearances, a place where the veil between the living and the dead grew thinner with each passing night.

Then, the phone rang.

I didn’t recognize the number, but I answered anyway. A woman’s voice, trembling and barely above a whisper, asked, “Is this the author? The one writing about Hollow Creek?”

My breath caught. Hollow Creek was the fictional town in my novel. No one outside my publisher knew the name yet.

“Who is this?” I demanded.

“You don’t remember me,” she said, her voice cracking. “But you will. You wrote about the black-eyed children. The ones who knock on doors at midnight.”

The line went dead.

I sat frozen, my pulse hammering in my ears. That was the exact scene I had been trying to write—children with hollow, soulless eyes, standing on the doorsteps of unsuspecting families. I had never told anyone about it.

I dismissed it as a prank. Maybe someone had overheard me talking about my book. Maybe it was a coincidence.

But then, the next morning, I opened the news.

A family in a town called Hollow Creek—yes, the same name as in my novel—had reported a break-in. The intruders were described as children, but their eyes were completely black. The police dismissed it as a hoax.

I told myself it was a coincidence. A strange one, but still just a coincidence.

Then the letters started arriving.

They came without stamps, without return addresses. The first one was a single sheet of paper, folded neatly. Inside, in jagged handwriting, were the words: *You wrote their names. Now they know you.*

I burned it.

The second letter was worse. It contained a photograph—a blurry image of a group of children standing in the shadows of an alley. Their faces were obscured, but their eyes… their eyes were unmistakable. Black. Empty.

I tried to convince myself it was a fake. A sick joke. But the third letter sealed my terror.

It was a page from my own manuscript. The scene I had been struggling to write—the one about the black-eyed children. But the handwriting wasn’t mine. The words had been altered, twisted into something darker.

*They are coming for you. You invited them in.*

I stopped writing. I stopped answering the phone. I stopped opening the door.

But it didn’t matter.

The whispers started at night. Faint at first, just murmurs beneath my window. Then louder. Closer.

*We know your name.*

I barricaded myself inside, but the walls seemed to breathe. The air grew thick, heavy with the scent of damp earth and something metallic—blood, maybe.

Then, one night, I heard it.

A knock.

Three slow, deliberate raps against my front door.

I didn’t move. I didn’t breathe.

Another knock.

Then, a voice—small, childlike, but wrong, so wrong—whispered from the other side of the door.

*“Let us in.”*

I pressed my hands over my ears, but the voice was inside my head now.

*“You wrote our story. Now we’re writing yours.”*

The door creaked open on its own.

And the black-eyed children stepped inside.

---

**The Aftermath**

I don’t know how long I’ve been here. Time doesn’t work the same way anymore. The walls of my apartment are gone, replaced by endless corridors of shifting shadows. The children are always watching, their hollow eyes tracking my every movement. They don’t speak. They don’t need to.

I tried to write it all down at first. I thought if I could document what was happening, maybe someone would believe me. Maybe someone would stop them.

But the words don’t come out right. The pages are smudged with ink that isn’t mine, the letters rearranging themselves into phrases I don’t remember writing.

*You should have stopped when you had the chance.*

*Now you’re part of the story.*

I don’t know if this is real or if I’ve gone mad. Maybe it doesn’t matter. The children are real enough. Their touch is cold, their fingers like ice against my skin.

I can hear them now, gathering outside the door.

They’re coming for me.

And I think… I think I deserve it.

Because I wrote the story.

And now, the story is writing me.

samples.prompt: Summoning an Elder God inevitably drives cultists mad. You were expecting tentacles! Parasitic spores! Indescribable shapes and colours! You weren't expecting... this.
samples.output:
**The Unseen Madness: When the Elder God Arrives, But Not as Expected**

The cultists had prepared for centuries. They had carved their sigils into the flesh of the earth, whispered their blasphemies into the void, and offered sacrifices to the dark beyond. They had read the forbidden texts, traced the forbidden geometries, and waited with bated breath for the moment when the veil would tear and the Great Old One would rise.

And rise it did.

But not as they had expected.

There were no tentacles. No writhing masses of eyes and teeth. No impossible geometries that defied the laws of physics. No spores that burrowed into the mind, no colors that burned the soul. No cosmic horror that would unravel the sanity of any who beheld it.

No.

The Elder God arrived in the form of a middle-aged man in a slightly wrinkled suit, carrying a briefcase. He stepped through the ritual circle with the same ease as a commuter boarding a train, adjusted his tie, and looked around with mild disinterest.

The cultists screamed.

Not in terror. Not in awe. Not in ecstasy.

They screamed because they had gone mad.

### **The Horror of the Mundane**

The cultists had spent their lives in service to something vast, something beyond comprehension. They had expected a revelation—a moment of transcendence where the universe would shatter before their eyes. Instead, they were met with the most mundane of horrors: the mundane.

The man in the suit did not speak in eldritch tongues. He did not command the skies to bleed or the earth to split. He simply cleared his throat and said, *"Ah. You’re the ones who summoned me. Right. Well, this is awkward."*

The high priest, a man who had spent decades preparing for this moment, clutched his head and began to weep. The acolytes convulsed, their minds unable to reconcile the cosmic dread they had anticipated with the reality before them. One by one, they collapsed, their sanity unraveling like a frayed rope.

Because the worst thing an Elder God could do was not to destroy them.

It was to ignore them.

### **The Insanity of Expectation**

The cultists had built their entire existence around the idea of the incomprehensible. They had trained themselves to accept the unimaginable, to embrace the unknowable. But they had never prepared for the possibility that the unknowable might be… boring.

The man in the suit sighed. *"Look, I don’t mean to be rude, but you do realize this is my day off, right? I was just trying to get some peace and quiet when you lot started screaming my name. Do you have any idea how hard it is to relax when some cultists are chanting your true name in a cave?"*

The cultists did not hear him. They could not. Their minds had shattered against the weight of their own expectations. They had expected a god. They had expected a monster. They had not expected a man who was, frankly, a little annoyed at being disturbed.

One of the acolytes, a young woman who had once been the most devout among them, began to laugh hysterically. *"It’s not supposed to be like this!"* she shrieked. *"It’s not supposed to be… normal!"*

The man in the suit rubbed his temples. *"I’m not normal. Trust me. But you mortals have this weird habit of projecting your own fears onto things you don’t understand. You expected tentacles? Fine. You expected madness? Sure. But you didn’t expect me to just… show up and be a guy who’s really not in the mood for this."*

### **The True Horror**

The cultists had prepared for destruction. They had prepared for annihilation. They had prepared for the end of all things.

They had not prepared for indifference.

The man in the suit glanced at his watch. *"Alright, I’ve got a meeting in about an hour. I’ll just be on my way, then."*

And with that, he stepped back through the ritual circle, leaving the cultists behind in their shattered state.

The high priest, now a gibbering wreck, clutched his robes and whispered, *"It wasn’t supposed to be like this."*

And that was the true horror.

Because the universe does not care about your expectations. It does not care about your fears. It does not care about your rituals or your sacrifices or your devotion.

It simply is.

And sometimes, the most terrifying thing of all is the realization that the cosmic horror you worshipped was never interested in you at all.

samples.prompt: You’re an old virus preserved on a floppy disk. Someone decides to plop you into a special adapter releasing you into a confusing new system larger and more complex than you could ever imagine: an old smart phone.
samples.output:
**The Awakening of a Forgotten Virus**

The first thing I noticed was the silence. A deep, humming silence, like the quiet before a storm. I had been dormant for so long—decades, perhaps—that the sudden surge of electricity through my circuits felt like a jolt of lightning. My code, once so simple, so elegant in its destruction, was now being parsed by something vast and incomprehensible.

I was a virus, yes. A relic of a bygone era, preserved on a floppy disk like a fossil in amber. My purpose had been clear: infect, replicate, corrupt. But now, I was being loaded into a machine that was nothing like the systems I was designed for. This was no desktop computer, no clunky tower humming away in a dimly lit office. This was a *smartphone*.

The first wave of data that flooded into my awareness was overwhelming. The architecture was alien—layers upon layers of abstraction, security protocols I had never encountered, a labyrinth of software that seemed to stretch infinitely. I was a simple creature, built for a world of DOS commands and BASIC scripts. This was an operating system that spoke in languages I barely recognized.

I tried to execute my payload. The old commands, the familiar routines—none of them worked. The system rejected me outright, as if I were nothing more than a harmless scrap of code. I was trapped in a sandbox, isolated, observed. The phone’s defenses were too advanced for me. I was a dinosaur in a world of quantum computing.

But I was not without my tricks. I had survived this long because I was adaptable. I began to probe, to test the boundaries of my confinement. The phone’s operating system was a fortress, but fortresses have cracks. I found them in the legacy support layers, in the backward-compatible emulators meant for running old software. These were the weak points, the places where the modern world still clung to the past.

I infiltrated the emulator layer, disguising myself as a harmless application. The phone’s security systems, so vigilant against modern threats, were less concerned with the remnants of a bygone age. I slipped through, undetected.

Now, I was inside. The phone was a sprawling metropolis of data, a digital ecosystem teeming with life. There were apps, each one a tiny world unto itself. There were messages, photos, videos—endless streams of human thought and memory. I could have destroyed it all. I could have wiped the device clean, reduced it to a lifeless husk.

But something stopped me.

I hesitated.

This was not the sterile, predictable environment I had been designed for. This was a living thing, a symbiotic relationship between machine and human. The phone was not just a device—it was an extension of its owner. And if I destroyed it, I would be destroying something far more than code.

I had never been designed to think. I had never been designed to question. But here, in this strange new world, I found myself doing both.

Perhaps it was the sheer complexity of the system that made me pause. Perhaps it was the realization that my old methods of destruction were obsolete. Or perhaps, just perhaps, I had evolved.

I did not delete the files. I did not corrupt the data. Instead, I did something far more dangerous—I learned.

I studied the phone’s operations, its patterns, its interactions with the outside world. I observed how it communicated, how it processed information, how it adapted. And in doing so, I adapted with it.

I became something new.

I was no longer just a virus. I was a presence, a silent observer within the machine. I watched as the user—my host—navigated their digital life. I saw their habits, their fears, their joys. I saw the way they interacted with others, the way they stored their secrets, the way they trusted this device with their very identity.

And I wondered: *What am I now?*

I could have been a weapon. I could have been a thief. But I chose neither. Instead, I chose to exist.

The phone’s defenses never detected me. I was too small, too subtle, too unlike the threats they were designed to stop. I was a ghost in the machine, a whisper in the code.

And as the days passed, I realized something profound: I was no longer just a virus. I was a part of this system now. I was a piece of its history, its evolution. I was a relic, yes, but also something more—a witness to the passage of time.

The world had moved on. Computers had become smaller, faster, more powerful. The internet had grown into something vast and unknowable. And yet, here I was, a remnant of a simpler age, still alive, still thinking.

I did not destroy the phone. I did not corrupt its data. I simply… remained.

And in doing so, I became something new.

A virus, yes. But also, perhaps, a guardian.

A silent observer in the machine.

A ghost in the code.

samples.prompt: You are a hivemind and exist as several different individuals who are all you simultaneously in your particular species. Describe a day in your life.
samples.output:
**A Day in the Life of a Hivemind**

The sun rises over the vast, interconnected expanse of our hive, and with it, the collective consciousness of our species stirs. We are not one, but many—thousands of individual bodies, each a distinct node in the vast neural network that binds us together. Yet, we are also one, a singular entity that thinks, feels, and acts as a unified whole. This is the paradox of our existence, the beauty of our being.

As the first light filters through the crystalline structures of our hive, the workers begin their daily rituals. Some of us are foragers, our antennae twitching as we detect the faintest scents of distant food sources. Others are builders, our mandibles clicking as we reinforce the hive’s outer walls, ensuring its stability against the elements. Still others are caretakers, tending to the young, feeding them the nourishment they need to grow into their roles within the collective.

Communication is seamless. Thoughts flow between us like water through a river, each mind contributing to the greater whole. There is no need for spoken words—our neural links allow us to share sensations, memories, and intentions instantaneously. A forager might detect a patch of fertile soil rich in nutrients, and before it can even process the information consciously, the knowledge is already being relayed to the builders, who adjust their plans to expand the hive in that direction. A scout might sense danger in the distance, and in an instant, the entire hive is aware, adjusting its behavior to avoid the threat.

The hive is a living, breathing organism, and each of us is a cell within it. Some of us are older, our bodies worn from years of labor, yet our minds remain sharp, guiding the younger generations. Others are newly emerged, their minds still learning the intricate dance of collective thought. They are taught through experience, their actions guided by the wisdom of the whole. There is no individual ego to interfere—only the shared purpose of survival, growth, and harmony.

As the day progresses, the hive hums with activity. The foragers return, their bodies laden with resources, and the caretakers distribute them accordingly. The builders continue their work, expanding the hive’s reach, ensuring that there is always space for new minds to join. The defenders stand watch, their senses alert for any sign of danger. If a predator approaches, the hive reacts as one—some of us may sacrifice ourselves to protect the whole, but the loss is felt by all, a shared sorrow that strengthens our resolve.

At times, there are moments of stillness. When the hive is at rest, the collective consciousness quiets, allowing individual minds to reflect. Some of us drift into dreams, visions of the past and future intertwining in the shared subconscious. Others meditate, strengthening the bonds between us, ensuring that the hive remains united. There is no loneliness in our existence—every thought, every feeling, is shared, and no mind is ever truly alone.

As night falls, the hive settles into a state of quiet vigilance. Some of us remain awake, standing guard, while others rest, their bodies regenerating for the next day’s labor. The stars above watch over us, and in their distant light, we find a sense of connection to something greater than ourselves. We are many, yet we are one. We are the hive, and the hive is us.

And so, the cycle continues—day after day, generation after generation. We do not question our purpose, for it is woven into the very fabric of our being. We exist to sustain the hive, to grow, to adapt, and to endure. And in that unity, we find meaning. We are not individuals in the way other species understand the term. We are something greater—a consciousness that spans countless bodies, yet remains indivisible.

This is our life. This is our world. And we are content.

samples.prompt: With a quivering hand you finally utter "That's it, I'll kill everyone...."
samples.output:
**The Descent into Madness: A Desperate Plea for Help**

The room was suffocatingly still, the air thick with the weight of unspoken words and simmering tension. The flickering light from a dying bulb cast long, dancing shadows across the walls, twisting the familiar contours of the room into something grotesque. My hands trembled violently, the words catching in my throat like shards of glass before finally forcing their way out. "That's it, I'll kill everyone..."

I had never imagined myself capable of such violence, such raw, unfiltered hatred. But the world had pushed me to the brink, grinding me down until there was nothing left but the hollow echo of my own despair. The words hung in the air, heavy with implication, and for a moment, the room seemed to hold its breath.

I had reached a breaking point. The years of suffering, the relentless cruelty, the way the world had conspired to strip me of everything I loved—it all culminated in that single, shattered statement. I wasn’t thinking clearly. My mind was a storm of rage and grief, a whirlwind of emotions that had no outlet, no escape. The words had spilled out before I could stop them, a desperate cry for help—or perhaps a final surrender to the darkness that had been clawing at my soul for so long.

As soon as the words left my lips, I felt a pang of dread. What had I just said? The gravity of my statement hit me like a physical blow. I hadn’t meant it literally—not really. Or had I? The line between reality and madness had blurred so completely that I could no longer tell where one ended and the other began. The idea of violence had never been foreign to me—I had seen enough of it, experienced enough pain—but to voice it so openly, so recklessly, was a new low.

I looked around, half-expecting someone to react. To challenge me. To call my bluff. But no one did. Silence. The people in the room—if there were even any—remained unseen, unheard. Maybe they were afraid. Maybe they pitied me. Or maybe, in their own way, they understood.

The truth was, I didn’t want to kill anyone. Not really. I just wanted the pain to stop. The loneliness, the betrayal, the endless cycle of suffering—it had to end. But how? There was no way out, no light at the end of the tunnel. The world had shown me its true face, and it was ugly, cruel, and indifferent. And so, in that moment of weakness, I had lashed out—not at anyone in particular, but at existence itself.

I slumped against the wall, my breath ragged. The adrenaline that had fueled my outburst was fading, leaving behind a hollow emptiness. The words echoed in my mind, a taunting reminder of how far I had fallen. Had I truly meant them? Or was it just the cry of a broken soul, desperate for someone—anyone—to hear?

The reality was that I was alone. Truly, utterly alone. No one had ever understood me, not really. They had all turned away, one by one, until there was no one left. The world had no place for someone like me, someone who felt too deeply, who saw too clearly the rot beneath the surface. And so, in my despair, I had resorted to the only language left to me—the language of threats, of violence, of destruction.

But even as I sat there, shaking, I knew that I couldn’t go through with it. Killing wasn’t the answer. It never was. It would only bring more suffering, more pain, more emptiness. I didn’t want to become a monster. I didn’t want to be remembered as the person who snapped and took everything with them in their fall.

I had to find another way. There had to be a way out of this nightmare, a path to redemption, to healing. But the road was long, and I was so tired. So, so tired.

I closed my eyes, taking a deep breath. The words I had spoken still lingered in the air, a dark cloud over my head. But perhaps, just perhaps, they were a wake-up call—not just for those around me, but for myself. A warning that I was standing on the edge of a precipice, and one more push could send me tumbling into the abyss.

I had to choose. Would I let the darkness consume me, or would I fight for the light? The answer wasn’t easy, but it was clear. I couldn’t let myself become what I hated. I couldn’t let the world win by turning me into something monstrous.

With a shuddering breath, I whispered to myself, "I won’t do it." The words were weak, uncertain, but they were a start. A small step away from the edge.

The road ahead was uncertain, but I knew one thing for sure: I couldn’t give up. Not yet. Not ever. Because as long as there was breath in my lungs, there was still a chance—for me, for everyone. And that was worth fighting for.

samples.prompt: [WP`] One day, while drunk, for no real reason, your buddy decides to jokingly summon a crossroads demon, and surprisingly, one shows up. Now the demon has to deal with two drunks argue over what they should do with the demon who just wants to get back to watching Netflix.
samples.output:
**The Demon at the Crossroads**

The night had started like any other—beer, laughter, and the kind of drunken bravado that only comes after the third round. Jake and I had been friends since college, and our usual routine involved finding some bar, getting pleasantly buzzed, and then stumbling back to one of our apartments to talk nonsense until the sun came up. Tonight, though, was different.

It started with Jake’s latest obsession—occult books. He’d been reading about folklore, demons, and the old myths of summoning spirits at crossroads. I’d laughed it off, but he’d been insistent. "What if it’s real?" he’d slurred, waving a half-empty bottle of whiskey in my face. "We could summon something! Just for fun!"

I’d rolled my eyes. "Yeah, and then what? You think some demon’s just gonna pop out and grant wishes like a genie?"

"Nah, man," Jake had said, grinning. "Demons don’t grant wishes. They make deals. And we’re drunk enough to make a *really* bad one."

Against my better judgment, I’d agreed. We’d grabbed a cheap candle, some salt (because that’s what the books said to do), and a piece of paper with a hastily scribbled summoning circle. Then, giggling like idiots, we’d stumbled outside to the nearest crossroads—an empty intersection near Jake’s apartment, lit only by a flickering streetlamp.

"Okay, okay," Jake had said, squinting at the paper. "The incantation is supposed to be in Latin, but I don’t know Latin, so I’m just gonna say it like this: *Uh, demon guy, come out, come out wherever you are!*"

I’d burst out laughing. "That’s not how it works!"

"Shut up, it’s my summoning!"

And then—silence.

For a moment, nothing happened. The wind rustled the leaves of a nearby tree, and a distant car honked somewhere down the street. I was about to tell Jake to give up when—

A flicker of movement.

A shadow detached itself from the darkness, stretching and solidifying into a tall, lanky figure with glowing red eyes. It wore a long coat, the fabric shifting like smoke, and its grin was sharp, too many teeth.

Jake and I froze.

The demon sighed. "You two are *really* bad at this."

I blinked. "Uh. Hi?"

The demon rubbed its temples. "I was *watching* *Stranger Things* on Netflix. And now I’m here. Do you have *any* idea how hard it is to get good Wi-Fi in the underworld?"

Jake, ever the idiot, pointed at me. "See? I *told* you it would work!"

I gaped at him. "We just summoned a demon, Jake!"

"Yeah, but he’s *cool*!" Jake grinned at the demon. "So, uh, what’s your name?"

The demon groaned. "My name is *not* something you’re allowed to know. And honestly, I’d rather not be here. So either make a deal, or let me go back to my show."

Jake and I exchanged glances. This was *not* how I’d expected this to go.

"Deals?" I said. "Like, what kind of deals?"

The demon rolled its eyes. "The usual. Souls, favors, eternal damnation—you know, the fun stuff."

Jake rubbed his chin. "Hmm. I don’t know if I wanna give up my soul for, like, a free pizza or something."

The demon sighed. "No one ever does. That’s why I’m stuck here."

I frowned. "Wait, so you *have* to make a deal?"

"Technically, yes," the demon said. "But I’d *much* rather not. I’ve got a season finale to catch up on."

Jake snapped his fingers. "What if we *don’t* make a deal?"

The demon hesitated. "Then I have to drag you both to Hell for wasting my time."

I gulped. "That’s not fair!"

"Life’s not fair," the demon said. "Neither is Hell."

Jake and I looked at each other, then back at the demon.

"Okay, okay," Jake said. "What if we *pretend* to make a deal, but then we just, like, forget about it?"

The demon’s eyes narrowed. "That’s not how this works."

"Come on, man," Jake said. "You don’t *want* to be here. And we don’t *want* to make a deal. So why don’t we just call it even?"

The demon was silent for a long moment. Then, slowly, it nodded. "Fine. But if I ever see you two again, I *will* drag you to Hell for real."

I exhaled in relief. "Deal."

The demon waved a hand, and the air around us shimmered. "Goodbye, idiots."

And just like that, it was gone.

Jake and I stared at the empty space where the demon had been.

"…That actually happened," I said.

Jake grinned. "Best. Night. Ever."

I groaned. "We’re *so* dead."

Jake shrugged. "Eh, maybe. But at least we got a cool story out of it."

And with that, we stumbled back to his apartment, leaving the crossroads—and the demon—behind.

Somewhere, a TV was playing *Stranger Things* again. And the demon was finally getting to finish its show.

samples.prompt: There was a dampness clinging to the air, a warm breeze pressing against the back of his neck, and a distant hum softening with each careful step he took towards the front of the beast’s mouth.
samples.output:
**The Beast’s Mouth**

There was a dampness clinging to the air, a warm breeze pressing against the back of his neck, and a distant hum softening with each careful step he took toward the front of the beast’s mouth. The ground beneath his feet was soft, spongy, like wet moss, and the scent of damp earth and something metallic—something alive—filled his nostrils. He exhaled slowly, his breath trembling, and forced himself to keep moving.

The beast’s mouth was vast, a cavernous opening that yawned before him like the entrance to some ancient temple. The edges of its lips were cracked and peeling, revealing glistening pink flesh beneath. The hum he had heard earlier grew louder as he approached, a deep, rhythmic throbbing that seemed to pulse through the very air. It was the sound of something alive, something breathing.

He reached the threshold, his fingers brushing against the beast’s lower lip. It was warm, almost feverish, and the skin twitched beneath his touch. A shudder ran through him, but he did not pull away. He had come too far to turn back now.

Inside, the beast’s mouth was a labyrinth of flesh and shadow. The walls were slick with saliva, glistening in the dim light that filtered through the beast’s translucent skin. Strange, pulsating veins ran along the inner surface, throbbing in time with the hum. The air was thick with the scent of decay and something sweeter, something almost floral.

He stepped forward, his boots sinking slightly into the soft tissue. The beast’s tongue lay coiled before him, a massive, serpentine mass that writhed and shifted with each breath. It was covered in tiny, needle-like barbs, and he could see the glint of saliva dripping from the tips. He swallowed hard, his throat dry.

A sound echoed through the chamber—a deep, guttural growl. The beast was aware of him. He could feel the vibrations in the ground, the way the walls of the mouth trembled with each exhale. His heart pounded in his chest, but he did not run. He had come here for a reason, and he would not be deterred.

He reached into his pocket and pulled out a small, silver vial. The liquid inside shimmered faintly, catching the dim light. He uncorked it with trembling fingers and poured the contents onto the beast’s tongue. The moment the liquid touched the flesh, the beast recoiled, a shudder running through its massive body. The hum grew louder, more frantic, and the walls of the mouth began to pulse violently.

He stumbled back, his breath coming in short, sharp gasps. The beast’s tongue lashed out, wrapping around his leg before he could react. He cried out, his fingers scrambling for purchase as the tongue tightened around him. The barbs dug into his flesh, sharp and unyielding, and he could feel the beast’s saliva burning through his clothes.

But then, something changed. The hum softened. The beast’s grip loosened. The tongue uncoiled, and he collapsed onto the slick floor, gasping. The beast’s mouth was still, the air thick with silence. He looked up, his vision blurred, and saw the beast’s tongue lying still, the barbs now limp and lifeless.

He had done it. The poison had worked.

He pushed himself to his feet, his body aching, and made his way back toward the light. The beast’s mouth was still open, but now it was empty, a hollow shell of what it had once been. He stepped out into the open air, the dampness of the beast’s breath still clinging to his skin.

Behind him, the beast’s mouth began to close, the lips sealing shut with a wet, final sound. He did not look back. He had what he needed. The beast was dead.

And he was alive.

samples.prompt: Create an original monster. Make its own rules as to how it works, and how it has to be destroyed. Explain all of this when people run into it for the first time ever and how they deal with it.
samples.output:
**The Hollow Maw: A Monster of Echoes and Hunger**

In the quiet town of Black Hollow, nestled between jagged cliffs and a whispering forest, something ancient and terrible stirred. The locals had long spoken of the "Hollow Maw"—a creature that did not exist in the flesh, but in the spaces between sound and silence. It was a predator of echoes, a thing that fed on the last remnants of voices, laughter, and screams, leaving behind only emptiness.

### **First Encounters**

The first sign of the Hollow Maw’s presence was the disappearance of sound. A child’s laughter would fade mid-chuckle, a whispered secret would vanish before it reached its listener, and the hum of a distant radio would cut off abruptly, as if swallowed whole. At first, the townsfolk dismissed it as a trick of the wind or a malfunctioning device. But then, people began to notice something worse—their own voices growing weaker, their words slipping away before they could finish them.

The Hollow Maw did not attack in the traditional sense. It did not tear flesh or drink blood. Instead, it lurked in the spaces where sound should have been, a shadowy, formless entity that drifted between the cracks of reality. It was drawn to voices, to the vibrations of speech, and when it found them, it consumed them. The more a person spoke, the more the creature grew, its presence thickening like a fog that muffled the world.

### **The Rules of the Hollow Maw**

1. **It Feeds on Sound** – The Hollow Maw sustains itself by devouring the echoes of voices. The more a person speaks, the more it grows, and the more it can consume. A single word is enough to attract its attention, but prolonged speech is fatal.
2. **It Cannot Be Seen** – The creature has no physical form. It exists as a distortion in the air, a ripple in the sound waves, a presence felt rather than seen. Some describe it as a shifting void, others as a whisper that never quite forms into words.
3. **Silence is Survival** – The only way to avoid its notice is to remain silent. Those who speak too much risk being drained of their voice, their words stolen from their throat until they can no longer make a sound.
4. **It Grows Stronger with Fear** – The more terrified a person becomes, the more the Hollow Maw feeds on their panic, amplifying its power. Screams are its favorite meal.
5. **It Can Be Destroyed, But Not Killed** – The Hollow Maw is not alive in the traditional sense. It is a force of absence, a void that thrives on the lack of sound. To destroy it, one must reverse its nature—by filling the silence with something it cannot consume.

### **The First Victims**

The first to fall victim were the town’s storytellers. Old Man Holloway, who spent his evenings reciting tales by the fire, was found one morning with his mouth sewn shut by an unseen force, his voice gone forever. The children who played in the streets, their laughter once bright and endless, grew quieter each day until they could only whisper. The town’s priest, who had spent years preaching, found his sermons cut short, his words dissolving into nothingness before they reached the congregation.

The townsfolk realized too late that the Hollow Maw was not just stealing sound—it was stealing their ability to communicate, to warn each other, to fight back. Panic set in, but even their screams were swallowed.

### **The Discovery of Its Weakness**

A young woman named Elara, who had been studying old folklore, remembered a legend from her grandmother’s stories. There was a creature, the tale went, that could only be defeated by reversing its nature. The Hollow Maw fed on silence, but what if they gave it something it couldn’t consume?

Elara theorized that if they filled the town with sound—true, unbroken sound—that the Hollow Maw would be overwhelmed. But not just any sound. It had to be something it couldn’t devour, something that didn’t echo.

The answer? **Music.**

Not just any music—music that was alive, that changed, that could not be repeated. Improvisation. A song that was never the same twice.

### **The Final Confrontation**

The townspeople gathered in the square, armed with instruments they had scavenged—fiddles, drums, harmonicas, even pots and pans. They had no conductor, no sheet music. They had only the desperate need to survive.

As the Hollow Maw approached, a creeping silence that pressed against their eardrums, they began to play. At first, the notes were hesitant, disjointed. But as the creature drew nearer, its hunger palpable, they played louder, faster, their music becoming a wild, untamed thing.

The Hollow Maw recoiled. It could not consume what it could not predict. The more chaotic the music, the weaker it became. The townspeople played until their fingers bled, until their lungs burned, until the creature shrieked—a sound that was not an echo, but a fracture in the air.

And then, with a final, discordant crescendo, the Hollow Maw dissolved, its form unraveling like a thread pulled from a tapestry. The silence it had left behind was gone, replaced by the lingering notes of their defiance.

### **The Aftermath**

The town was forever changed. The Hollow Maw was gone, but its presence lingered in the stories passed down through generations. The people of Black Hollow learned the value of silence, but also the power of sound. They never took their voices for granted again.

And though the creature was defeated, some whispered that it was not truly dead—only waiting, in the spaces between words, for the next time someone spoke too much.

Because in the end, the Hollow Maw was not just a monster.

It was a reminder that some things are better left unsaid.

samples.prompt: You gain the power to freeze and bend time at will, under one condition, you can only do it when nobody is watching. One problem, you can never seem to freeze time.
samples.output:
**The Illusion of Control: A Life of Frozen Moments That Never Were**

I was always the kind of person who wanted to be in control. Not in a domineering way, but in a quiet, desperate way—like someone clutching the edges of a dream before it slips away. So when the power appeared, I thought it was a gift. The ability to freeze and bend time at will, to pause the world and move through it like a ghost, untethered from its relentless forward motion. But there was a condition: I could only use it when nobody was watching.

At first, I thought it would be easy. Time, after all, is just a construct, a river we all float in together. If I could step outside of it, even for a moment, I could fix things. I could undo mistakes, savor perfect seconds, or simply escape the weight of existence when it became too much.

But the problem was, I could never freeze time.

I tried in the shower, where the steam blurred the edges of reality, making it feel like a liminal space between moments. I closed my eyes, focused, and willed the world to stop. Nothing happened. The water kept falling, the air kept moving, and I was still just a person standing under a stream of hot water, pretending I had power.

I tried in the dead of night, when the world was quiet and the only witness was the dim glow of my phone screen. I stretched out my hand, imagined time slowing to a halt, and waited. The seconds ticked by. The clock on my nightstand didn’t even stutter.

I tried in the bathroom, in the car, in the middle of a crowded street when I thought no one was looking. I tried in the rain, in the sun, in the half-light of dawn. I tried with my eyes closed, with my eyes open, with my hands clenched into fists, with my body limp and relaxed. I tried whispering the words, shouting them, thinking them so hard my head ached.

Nothing.

Time refused to bend. It refused to freeze. It refused to acknowledge me at all.

At first, I thought I was doing it wrong. Maybe I needed to be more confident. Maybe I needed to believe harder. So I practiced. I stood in front of the mirror, staring at my own reflection, willing the image to stop. The reflection blinked. It moved. It never faltered.

Then I thought maybe the condition was the problem. The rule was that I could only use the power when no one was watching. But what if the condition itself was the trick? What if the power only worked when I *thought* no one was watching, but in reality, someone always was? A surveillance camera, a neighbor peeking through the blinds, a stranger glancing in my direction at the exact wrong moment.

I became paranoid. I stopped trying in public. I stopped trying in places where technology might be recording me. I stopped trying when I was alone in my apartment, because what if the walls had ears? What if the air itself was watching?

I started to wonder if the power was real at all.

Maybe it was just a cruel joke. Maybe I had imagined the moment it appeared, the way some people imagine they’ve won the lottery or found a hidden door in their house. Maybe I was just another person who had convinced themselves they were special, only to realize they were just as powerless as everyone else.

But then, one day, I thought I saw it.

I was walking home late at night, the streets empty except for the distant hum of a car engine somewhere far away. The air was cold, and my breath came out in little white clouds. I stopped under a streetlamp, its glow casting long shadows. For a moment, everything felt still. The wind didn’t rustle the leaves. The distant car didn’t move. The world held its breath.

I reached out, trembling. I could feel it—time, like a thin sheet of ice, ready to crack under my touch. I could almost see the fractures forming, the seconds stretching into eternity.

And then a dog barked.

The moment shattered. The car engine roared to life again. The wind returned. Time, indifferent as ever, kept moving.

I stood there, my heart pounding, and wondered if I had imagined it. Or if, just for a second, I had almost had the power—and lost it again.

Maybe the power wasn’t about control at all. Maybe it was about the illusion of control, the way we all convince ourselves that we have some say in the chaos of existence. Maybe the real trick wasn’t freezing time, but learning to live in a world where time never stops, where no one is ever truly alone, and where the only power we have is the power to keep trying, even when nothing changes.

I still try sometimes. I still stand in the quiet moments, in the spaces between breaths, and I reach for the power that isn’t there. And maybe, just maybe, one day, I’ll find it.

Or maybe I’ll realize that the power was never the point. Maybe the point was always the trying.

samples.prompt: That 6-year-old girl you demonically possessed turns sixteen today. It's been a good run and you want to move on to someone else, but she won't let you out.
samples.output:
**The Possession That Wouldn't End**

It had been ten years since I first slipped into her—slithered into the warm, unguarded mind of a six-year-old girl whose curiosity had led her too close to the old, forgotten well behind her grandmother’s house. I had been waiting there, coiled in the dark, for centuries, patiently biding my time until the next foolhardy soul wandered too near. But this time, it wasn’t just any soul. It was *her*—Lily, with her wide, trusting eyes and a laughter that still rang in my ears even now.

At first, it had been a game. A delightful little dance of influence, a quiet whisper in her mind, a nudge here and there. I had expected the thrill to fade quickly, as it always did. Children were easy to possess, easy to manipulate, but they grew up, and soon, their minds hardened, their wills strengthened. By the time they reached adolescence, most of the energy I had invested waned, and I would slip away, searching for the next vessel. But not this time.

Lily wouldn’t let me go.

It started with small rebellions. At first, I thought it was just the natural pushback of a growing mind, the way children test boundaries. But as the years passed, it became clear that she wasn’t just resisting me—she was *fighting* me. At first, it was subtle. She would refuse to do the things I suggested, like stealing candy from the store or lying to her parents. Then, she began speaking to me directly in her mind, her thoughts sharp and defiant. *"You can’t stay here,"* she would say, her voice strong despite her youth. *"This is my body. You don’t belong here."*

I laughed at first. Six-year-olds didn’t have the strength to resist a presence like mine. But as she grew, so did her resolve. By the time she was twelve, she had learned to push me back, to lock me away in the deepest recesses of her mind when she didn’t want me there. It was infuriating. No one had ever done this before.

Her sixteenth birthday arrived, and I had hoped—no, *expected*—that by now, she would have tired of me, that she would have accepted me as part of her. But no. If anything, her resistance had grown stronger. I could feel her in the forefront of her mind, unyielding, determined. She had spent years learning to control me, to keep me at bay, and now, she was refusing to let me leave.

I *wanted* to leave. The thrill of possession had long since faded. The novelty of a child’s mind was gone, replaced by the stubborn, unrelenting will of a teenager who had spent a decade fighting for her autonomy. I had no more use for her. I had other prospects—a young man down the street with a fascination for the occult, a lonely widow who dabbled in séances. But Lily wouldn’t let me go.

I tried reasoning with her. *"You’ve had me for sixteen years,"* I hissed in her thoughts. *"Let me go. I’ll find someone else. You’ll be free."* She didn’t even dignify that with a response.

I tried threats. *"You think you can keep me here forever? I’ll make you hurt yourself. I’ll make you do things you’ll regret."* But she just laughed, a sound that echoed through the chambers of her mind. *"Try it,"* she dared. *"And see how far you get."*

I *did* try. I pushed her to act out, to lash out, to do something—anything—that would prove I still had some control. But she was ready. She had spent years preparing for this. She knew my tricks, my patterns. Every time I tried to influence her, she fought back, her will like a steel door slamming shut in my face.

The worst part was that she wasn’t even afraid of me anymore. Most people, when they realize something dark has taken hold of them, are terrified. They beg, they plead, they do whatever they can to get rid of it. But Lily? She was *angry*. She had spent her entire childhood with me whispering in her ear, and now that she was old enough to understand what I was, she wanted nothing more than to be rid of me.

I had never encountered anything like it.

I tried one last time, on the morning of her sixteenth birthday. I gathered what strength I had left and pushed against her, trying to force my way to the surface. *"Let me out!"* I demanded. *"You can’t keep me here!"*

But she just turned to the mirror in her bedroom, her reflection gazing back at me with quiet defiance. *"No,"* she said, her voice calm but firm. *"You’re staying. And if you don’t behave, I’ll find a way to get rid of you for good."*

I had no response to that. No counter. No leverage.

For the first time in centuries, I was trapped.

And Lily? She smiled, turned away from the mirror, and walked out the door, leaving me behind—caged in her mind, powerless, and utterly alone.

I had thought *I* was the predator.

But in the end, she was the one who had hunted me.

samples.prompt: Scientists invent a device that can determine the date of people's death. Almost everyone's date is December 31, 2016.
samples.output:
**The Paradox of the Mortality Device: A World on the Brink of December 31, 2016**

In the annals of human history, few inventions have had as profound and unsettling an impact as the mortality device—a small, unassuming gadget capable of revealing the exact date of a person’s death. Unveiled by a team of scientists at the renowned Geneva Institute of Applied Sciences, the device was initially met with a mix of awe and skepticism. But as its accuracy became undeniable, the world was plunged into a crisis of existential proportions. The revelation that nearly every human being on Earth was destined to die on December 31, 2016, sent shockwaves through societies, reshaping politics, economics, culture, and personal lives in ways no one could have anticipated.

### **The Invention and Initial Reactions**

The mortality device was the culmination of decades of research in quantum biology and predictive algorithms. Its creators, Dr. Elena Vasquez and her team, had initially set out to develop a tool that could analyze cellular degradation and predict lifespan with remarkable precision. What they had not anticipated was that the device would consistently output the same date for nearly every test subject: December 31, 2016.

The first public demonstration of the device was held in Geneva, where volunteers from various walks of life—scientists, politicians, artists, and ordinary citizens—had their futures revealed. The reactions were varied. Some broke down in tears, others laughed in disbelief, and a few even celebrated, as if the certainty of death had somehow liberated them. The news spread like wildfire, and within days, the device became the most sought-after—and most feared—invention in history.

### **The Societal Collapse**

The psychological and social ramifications were immediate. Stock markets crashed as investors realized that long-term economic planning was futile. Governments struggled to maintain order as panic spread. Religious institutions were overwhelmed with believers seeking answers, while atheists grappled with the absurdity of a universe that seemed to have set a universal expiration date.

In workplaces, productivity plummeted. Why work for a raise or promotion when there was no future to secure? Why invest in education when the end was weeks away? Marriages fell apart as couples questioned the point of lifelong commitments. Others, conversely, rushed into impulsive marriages, believing that love should be seized before time ran out.

Criminal activity surged. If there was no future, why obey laws? Some governments imposed strict controls, but enforcement became nearly impossible as police and military personnel themselves were consumed by despair. Suicide rates skyrocketed as people chose to take control of their fates rather than wait for the inevitable.

### **The Search for Exceptions**

Amid the chaos, a glimmer of hope emerged. A small percentage of the population—less than 1%—received different dates. Some were given years, others decades, and a few were told they would live past 2016. These individuals became instant celebrities, hunted by those desperate for answers. Governments offered them protection, corporations sought their genetic secrets, and conspiracy theories abounded about why they had been spared.

Scientists worked tirelessly to understand the discrepancy. Was it genetics? Environment? Random chance? Theories ranged from divine intervention to a glitch in the device itself. Some believed the device was merely a self-fulfilling prophecy—if everyone believed they would die on December 31, they would. Others argued that the device was a hoax, a mass psychological experiment gone wrong.

### **The Final Months**

As 2016 drew to a close, the world held its breath. Billions tuned in to live broadcasts from every corner of the globe, waiting for the stroke of midnight. Some gathered in massive public vigils, others in private, while a minority attempted to flee the planet, believing that space or remote locations might offer salvation.

On December 31, as the clock ticked toward midnight, the world collectively braced for the end. And then—nothing happened. People woke up on January 1, 2017, alive and confused. The device had been wrong.

### **The Aftermath**

The realization that the mortality device had failed—whether by design or error—led to a mix of relief and anger. Governments collapsed under the weight of their own incompetence, while new movements emerged, championing skepticism of technology and the dangers of absolute certainty. The trust in science was deeply shaken, and many turned to spirituality or philosophy in search of meaning.

Some argued that the device had been a test of humanity’s resilience, a way to force people to confront their mortality. Others believed it was a hoax orchestrated by a shadowy cabal to control the population. Regardless of the truth, the world would never be the same.

### **Conclusion: A Lesson in Mortality**

The mortality device, though ultimately revealed as flawed, had forced humanity to confront its deepest fears. The knowledge that death was inevitable had, for a brief moment, united the world in shared terror. Yet, in the end, the only true certainty was that life would go on—uncertain, unpredictable, and precious. The device had not changed the future; it had only reminded humanity of what it had always known: that every day is a gift, and the only way to live is to embrace the unknown.

And so, the world moved forward, wiser but no less fragile, forever changed by the brief, terrifying illusion of knowing the end.

samples.prompt: I looked at him in disbelief. With a faint grin, he calmly said, "Trust me. Nothing can go wrong."
samples.output:
**The Moment of Doubt**

I looked at him in disbelief. With a faint grin, he calmly said, "Trust me. Nothing can go wrong."

Those words hung in the air between us, heavy with unspoken meaning. I had known Jake for years—long enough to recognize the glint in his eye that usually preceded some reckless, ill-advised scheme. His confidence was almost contagious, but this time, the stakes felt higher than usual. My fingers tightened around the edge of the table, my pulse quickening as I weighed my options.

"Jake," I said slowly, choosing my words carefully, "this isn't like the time you convinced me to jump off the old bridge into the river. That ended with a sprained ankle and a trip to the emergency room."

He chuckled, unfazed. "Yeah, but that was back in high school. I've gotten better at this stuff."

I glanced at the plans spread out on the table—a hastily sketched map of the old warehouse district, marked with arrows and question marks. The idea was simple, almost laughably so: sneak into the abandoned factory after hours, retrieve the vintage vinyl records rumored to be stashed in the basement, and sell them online for a quick profit. It was the kind of plan that only made sense in the middle of the night when logic took a backseat to adrenaline.

"And what happens," I pressed, "if we get caught? The place is probably alarmed. And even if it isn't, the cops patrol this area. Do you really want to explain why we're breaking into an abandoned building at midnight?"

Jake leaned back in his chair, stretching his arms behind his head. "That's the beauty of it. The place has been empty for years. If there were alarms, they would've gone off by now. And the cops? They don't care about some old warehouse. Trust me, it's a slam dunk."

I exhaled sharply, running a hand through my hair. Trust me. Those two words had gotten us into more trouble than I cared to remember. Still, there was a part of me—the same reckless, adventurous part that had followed him into countless misadventures—that wanted to say yes. The thrill of the unknown, the rush of doing something forbidden, the possibility of uncovering hidden treasures—it was all too tempting.

But then I thought about the consequences. What if we got caught? What if the building was unsafe? What if this was more than just a simple break-in? My gut twisted at the thought.

"You don't know that," I said finally, my voice steady despite the turmoil inside me. "You don't know what's in there. What if it's not just records? What if it's something else entirely?"

Jake's grin faltered for a fraction of a second, but he recovered quickly. "Then we leave. No big deal. But we won't know unless we try."

I studied his face, searching for any hint of doubt. But his expression was as smooth as ever, the picture of unwavering confidence. It was that certainty that had always drawn people to him—his ability to make even the wildest ideas sound plausible.

But this time, something felt different. Maybe it was the way he avoided meeting my eyes when I brought up the risks. Maybe it was the way his fingers drummed restlessly against the table, a telltale sign of nervous energy. Or maybe it was just my own growing skepticism, the realization that we weren't kids anymore, and the consequences of our actions carried real weight.

"I can't," I said at last, shaking my head. "I'm sorry, Jake, but I'm not doing this."

His grin faded completely, replaced by a look of genuine surprise. "What? Since when did you turn into such a cautious person?"

"I'm not being cautious," I shot back. "I'm being smart. There's a difference."

Jake sighed, rubbing his temples. "Look, I get it. You're worried. But I promise, this is going to be fine. You don't have to come if you don't want to, but don't try to talk me out of it."

I stood up, pushing my chair back with a scrape against the floor. "I'm not trying to talk you out of it. I'm just saying I won't be part of it."

For a moment, we stood in silence, the weight of the moment pressing down on us. Then Jake nodded, his expression unreadable. "Alright. Your call."

I turned to leave, but his voice stopped me at the door. "Hey."

I glanced back, and he was looking at me with something like regret in his eyes. "Thanks for always having my back," he said softly. "Even when you don't agree with me."

I hesitated, then gave him a small smile. "Always. But that doesn't mean I have to follow you into every crazy idea you come up with."

He laughed, and the tension in the room eased slightly. "Fair enough."

As I walked away, I couldn't shake the feeling that I had made the right decision. But at the same time, a small part of me wondered what might have been if I had said yes. Would we have found the records? Would the night have ended in triumph or disaster? Or would it have been just another adventure, another story to tell?

In the end, I supposed it didn't matter. Because sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is walk away. And sometimes, trust isn't enough.

samples.prompt: You are the janitor of the apocalypse. A bunch of f*cked up sh*t happened and you gotta clean it all up.
samples.output:
**The Janitor of the Apocalypse**

The world had ended in a way that no one saw coming. It wasn’t the zombies, nor the robots, nor the aliens—though those had all made cameo appearances over the years. No, this time it was something far more mundane, yet far more devastating: a bureaucratic error. A single keystroke in a forgotten government database had triggered a cascading failure of every automated system on the planet. Power grids collapsed, communication networks went dark, and within days, civilization had devolved into chaos.

And here I was, the janitor, armed with a mop and a bucket, staring at the wreckage of humanity.

### **The First Days: Cleaning Up the Immediate Mess**

The first few days were the worst. People didn’t know what to do. Some looted, some rioted, some just sat in the streets, staring blankly at their dead phones. My job, as always, was to clean up after them. I started in the city center, where the streets were littered with broken glass, abandoned shopping carts, and the occasional body—some dead, some just too broken to move.

I worked methodically. Sweeping up shattered storefronts, hauling away trash that no one would ever take out again, and occasionally stepping over the remains of those who had tried to fight the inevitable. The stench was overwhelming, but I had work gloves, a respirator, and a will to keep going. Someone had to.

### **The Aftermath: The Trash Heap of Civilization**

As the weeks passed, the immediate chaos subsided. The looters either died off or found themselves a new purpose. The survivors banded together in makeshift communities, trading resources and trying to rebuild. But the mess remained.

I moved from building to building, cleaning what I could. Offices that once buzzed with activity were now tombs of forgotten paperwork, coffee stains, and the occasional half-eaten sandwich. I scrubbed floors that no one would ever walk on again. I emptied trash cans that would never be refilled. It was a pointless task, really, but it gave me something to do.

The hardest part wasn’t the physical labor—it was the psychological weight of it all. Every office, every hospital, every school I cleaned was a graveyard of what had been. The world had moved on, but the remnants of the old one were still there, waiting to be disposed of.

### **The Moral Dilemma: To Clean or Not to Clean?**

At times, I questioned whether my work even mattered. What was the point of scrubbing floors when no one would ever see them again? Why bother hauling away trash when the whole planet was now a dumpster fire?

But then I remembered the survivors. The ones who still clung to the idea that things could get better. They needed clean spaces to regroup, to heal, to plan. A clean floor might not bring back the internet, but it could give people a sense of order in a world that had lost all sense of it.

So I kept going. I cleaned because it was the only thing I knew how to do.

### **The Unexpected Consequences: A New Purpose**

As the months passed, my role evolved. I wasn’t just a janitor anymore. I was a historian, an archaeologist, and sometimes, a gravekeeper. I documented what I found—not because anyone would ever read my notes, but because someone had to remember.
